entry.title: Perceptions about Jekyll during my development

link.title: Perceptions about Jekyll during my development

entry.content:
This is my second post in this blog. Here I'll try to share some perceptions about [Jekyll](jekyll_homepage). I've developing in Jekyll since decided to wrote a **Business Card** and a simple blog to share some ideas and thougths.
#### So, you asked me: "What's Jekyll?"
Let me resume: Jekyll it's a static website generator based in [Markdown](markdown_homepage) and Ruby to build a simple website. This is the default engine used in [GitHub Pages](github_pages).
You can use CSS and HTML to build a template, some JS where you want and build some static files to upload into a GitHub Pages enabled repository. As you can use CSS, some modifications are simple: you can change fonts with [Google Fonts](google_fonts), for example.
> This website it's using Muli and Bree Serif at the time of this post
The social links used in the blue bar it's based on HTML/CSS and variables from `_config.yml` file of Jekyll application. You can read [Jekyll Documentation](jekyll_docs) to learn more about.
#### And "How to write posts?"
The process about writing posts it's very simple. Jekyll provide a folder called `_posts` to keep your source files, based on **Markdown** - this files contains text and formatting of your posts.
The post file has a pattern for name: it's based on the title and date time, as `YYYY-MM-DD-my-post-title.md`. The file used to generate this post was named as `2019-06-07-perceptions-about-jekyll.md`. That last part will be used as URL of the post.
![Files used to produce posts](/../assets/images/posts/2019-06-07-post-names.png)
All formatting of post are based on Markdown. **Bold** used with `**bold text**`, *Italic* with `*italic text*` and titles with `#`. I can even make a small list of links at end of file to make easier link maintenance.
![List of links at end of Markdown file](/assets/images/posts/2019-06-07-link-list.png)
